title: Enhancing Spatial Navigation Using Non-Invasive Brain Stimulation
description_brief:
Remembering how to travel from one location to another is critical in everyday life, yet this vital ability declines with normal aging and can be further affected by conditions that disproportionately affect the elderly, such as vision loss or progressive dementia. Human and animal research has shown that two distinct memory systems interact during navigation. The first, referred to as allocentric navigation, is very flexible and uses spatial knowledge of key features or landmarks to develop and use a mental map of the environment. This approach involves brain regions that are critical for new learning and memory but that decline with age. The second, referred to as egocentric navigation, is inflexible and relies on "habit" memories that link specific features with specific directions. This approach relies on brain regions that are critical for "automatic" responses and that are relatively unaffected by age.

The main problem is that allocentric navigation declines with age and is accompanied increased dependence on egocentric navigation. This change increases the risk of becoming disoriented or "lost" when traveling in unfamiliar areas or even when traveling new routes in familiar areas. Therefore, the main goal of this project is to examine whether non-invasive brain stimulation, specifically transcranial direct current stimulation, can improve allocentric navigation in healthy older adults and patients with mild cognitive impairment.

Participants will complete two functional magnetic resonance imaging sessions while learning new environments. Before one of these sessions, participants will receive active brain stimulation over the parietal cortex. Before the other session, participants will receive sham brain stimulation over the parietal cortex. The effects of this stimulation will be evaluated using both an allocentric and an egocentric memory test. Physiologic effects will be evaluated using both task-based and resting-state MRI.

groups.title: Cognitively Intact -Active Then Sham tDCS
groups.description: All participants received active and sham transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS). Participants were randomized to order (i.e., half received active tDCS in the first session and sham in the second session; the other half received the opposite).

groups.title: Cognitively Intact - Sham Then Active
groups.description: All participants received active and sham transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS). Participants were randomized to order (i.e., half received active tDCS in the first session and sham in the second session; the other half received the opposite).

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Accuracy in Centimeters From Target Location for Allocentric
outcomeMeasures.description: 1 active tDCS; 1 sham tDCS for each measure. Participants touched a screen (using a ELO 19" touchscreen monitor) to document the location of the landmark. The distance between the actual vs. selected location served as the dependent measure.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Computer errors caused missing data for a subset (n=4) of participants; those data have simply been omitted from analyses below.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Outcome assessed after each of 2 sessions (estimated within 1 week of each other)

analyses.groupDescription: RM ANCOVA (covarying order) for cognitively intact groups
RM ANCOVA (covarying order) for MCI group

outcomeMeasures.title: Hippocampal BOLD Signal During Task-based fMRI
outcomeMeasures.description: BOLD signal change comparing active to sham tDCS during Allocentric navigation (i.e., active HD-tDCS \> sham HD-tDCS). Activation maps thresholded at p\<.01 with minimum cluster size of 5 voxels.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Participants from each group were excluded due to movement artifact that invalidated fMRI data.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: change between active and sham tDCS sessions (<1month)

analyses.statisticalComment: Main effect of stimulation covarying session order

outcomeMeasures.title: Dorsal Attention Network Connectivity During Resting-state fMRI
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in resting state functional connectivity strength between active and sham tDCS sessions. Strength is measured by Pearson r correlations between nodes, which are z-transformed, and summated.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Participants from each group were excluded due to movement artifact that invalidated fMRI data.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: change between active and sham tDCS sessions (<1month)

drug: transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) over parietal cortex (active stimulation)
placebo: sham transcranial direct current stimulation (sham tDCS)
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is non-invasive brain stimulation (transcranial direct current stimulation, tDCS) applied over the parietal cortex to improve allocentric spatial navigation in older adults and people with mild cognitive impairment. The goal is to improve a cognitive ability (allocentric navigation / spatial memory), not to target Alzheimer’s pathology (e.g., amyloid or tau). tDCS is a neuromodulation technique that modulates cortical excitability and is used experimentally to try to enhance cognitive function. citeturn0search12turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details from the trial description — intervention: active tDCS over parietal cortex; control: sham tDCS; population: healthy older adults and patients with mild cognitive impairment; outcomes: allocentric and egocentric memory tests plus task-based and resting-state fMRI. This matches the "cognitive enhancer" category because the intended effect is to improve cognitive performance (navigation/memory) rather than to modify underlying AD pathology. Evidence/background on tDCS (mechanism, use in cognitive research, and sham control designs) from web search: (1) overview of tDCS mechanism and uses; (2) lab/clinical descriptions of tDCS procedures and cognitive applications. citeturn0search12turn0search0

Web search results (selected): (a) Transcranial direct-current stimulation — general overview, mechanism, uses and mixed evidence for cognition. (source: Wikipedia). citeturn0search12 (b) Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation — lab resource describing tDCS technique, anodal/cathodal effects, and use on cognitive tasks. citeturn0search0

Reflect: Classification check — the trial tests a neuromodulation method to improve a specific cognitive ability (allocentric navigation) using active vs sham stimulation and fMRI outcome measures. It does not test a biologic (e.g., monoclonal antibody) or a small-molecule drug targeting AD pathology, nor does it primarily target neuropsychiatric symptoms (agitation, depression). Therefore the correct category is "cognitive enhancer." No pharmacologic drug is involved; the sham condition is the appropriate placebo control for tDCS. No ambiguity remains based on the provided description.
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is non-invasive brain stimulation (anodal/cathodal tDCS) applied to parietal cortex to modulate cortical excitability and improve allocentric spatial navigation and memory — i.e., it aims to enhance cognition via neuromodulation and plasticity rather than to modify Alzheimer’s-specific pathologies (amyloid, tau, ApoE, etc.). This aligns with mechanisms of synaptic plasticity and neuroprotection. citeturn0search7turn0search0

Act: Key extracted trial details — intervention: active transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) over parietal cortex with sham control; population: older adults and people with mild cognitive impairment; outcomes: allocentric/egocentric navigation tasks and task/resting-state fMRI. tDCS over parietal cortex has been used to modulate navigation-related networks and has shown polarity-dependent changes in activation/connectivity during allocentric navigation. citeturn0search5turn0search3

Evidence (web search results): (1) Systematic reviews and animal studies report that tDCS can modulate synaptic plasticity (LTP/LTD-related signaling, BDNF) and learning/memory processes, supporting a plasticity-based mechanism. citeturn0search0 (2) Meta-analyses in MCI/AD populations show mixed but sometimes positive short-term cognitive effects of tDCS. citeturn0search1 (3) fMRI/behavioral studies demonstrate that parietal tDCS can alter activation and connectivity during spatial navigation tasks. citeturn0search5 (4) Reviews summarize tDCS action as modulation of cortical excitability (anodal generally excitatory, cathodal inhibitory) and its use as a cognitive enhancement/rehabilitation tool. citeturn0search7

Reflect: Classification check — given the mechanism (neuromodulation that acts via changing cortical excitability and promoting synaptic plasticity/neuroplasticity) and the cognitive-enhancement aim (improving navigation/memory rather than targeting molecular AD pathology), the most specific CADRO match is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. There is no indication this trial targets amyloid, tau, inflammation, vasculature, or other CADRO categories, nor is it a diagnostic-only (so T) Other is not appropriate). No multi-target pharmacologic mechanism is described, so R) Multi-target is not indicated.
